<tr>
<td class="rowhead1">Summary</td><td colspan="99">This course aims to provide a basic understanding of the Laws of Newtonian Mechanics for bodies and systems of bodies in plane motion, and to achieve proficiency in their use in conjunction with kinematic principles for a range of mechanical engineering applications.<br/>
<br/>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="rowhead1">Course description</td><td colspan="99">
    
    1. Dynamics of Particles<br/>
Newton's Laws of Motion and the nature of forces; D'Alembert approach; dynamical laws of single particle; dynamical theorems for systems of particles; Linear and Angular momentum; mass centre properties; motion in polar coordinates; Coriolis acceleration. Central Force motion and orbits.<br/>
<br/>
2. Systems of Bodies<br/>
Rigid body as a model; dynamical laws for rigid bodies in pure translation, fixed axis rotation and general plane motion; inertia couple; moments of inertia; inertia theorems; rolling versus sliding. Kinematic relations between interacting bodies: circular motion, gear drives, belts and pulleys, rolling on a plane. Applications to coupled systems, power transmission, simple vehicles, rotational unbalance, static and dynamic-balancing of rotors; introduce balancing of reciprocating mechanisms.<br/>
<br/>
3. Work - Energy Approach<br/>
Kinetic and potential energy; work and power; work-energy theorems applied to system calculations; the conservative system as a special case.<br/>
<br/>
4. Oscillatory Motion<br/>
Introduction to oscillations; differential equations of translational and rotational SDF systems, free vibration, natural frequency; damping and critical damping; introduction to resonance, features of vibratory phenomena.<br/>
<br/>
5. Gyroscopic Torque<br/>
Introduction to gyroscopic torque and gyroscopic effects; angular momentum vector of a rotor; precession applications.
    
    
</td>
</tr>

<!-- Learning outcomes, FB 1/4/11 add other learning outcomes for ECA -->
<table class="sitstablegrid">
<caption>Learning Outcomes</caption>
<tr>
<td>
    On completion of this course, the student will be able to:
    <ol style="font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit;">
<li>Model mechanical systems as plane assemblies of masses and inertias, and draw clear accurate linked free-body diagrams.</li><li>Identify kinematic relations between coupled elements using cables, gears and pure rolling.</li><li>Calculate moments of inertias of a range of assemblies, using parallel axes and perpendicular axes theorems.</li><li>Formulate energy expressions for systems and use concepts of work and power to determine motion.</li><li>Understand the properties of single degree of freedom oscillatory systems, and the importance of resonant systems in engineering.</li>
</ol>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
